replies.text:
The world building is so deep and intentional most would think it's an adaptation.  Add the cinema language of long takes and amazing use of IMAX perspective shifts and it makes this seeming genre movie (another topic that critics often despise) with hidden depth that movie that was driven purely by word of mouth (got me to see it twice) the movie of the year.  

However, the beef was more that Coogler gets this movie back from the studio in 25 years, this probably pissed off the CEOs, old media guard and tech billionaires than anything else.  It's the black ownership that made the Penske Media (owners of Deadline, Variety, Rolling Stone) take notice, even setting rumors of the studio heads being fired for making the deal with Coogler as cause.  

The double standards are not lost on me, but I've lived long enough to see them.

replies.text:
@JCfromouterspace‚Äã‚Äã‚Å†why because people were holed up hiding from vampires? 

Vampires dying in sunlight is a typical vampire trope. That‚Äôs not what makes the film original. All vampire movies would be the same if it simply came down to lore. Aside from some of the typical vampire lore there were aspects of Sinner‚Äôs vampires that were specific to the movie. 

I don‚Äôt see the dusk til dawn comparison aside from two brothers in a bar. The tone of dusk til dawn is very different. It‚Äôs like a horror comedy and it definitely doesn‚Äôt explore any complex themes. It‚Äôs an action movie turned gore fest and it doesn‚Äôt even take itself seriously. 30 days of night is only similar in the sense people are surviving vampires but for 30 days. Is 30 days of night a combination of storm of the century and salems lot? Marlow and Barlow, perhaps. 

Thematically, tonally, cinematically all three are very different movies. 30 days of night and dusk til dawn are not similar either except they are vampire movies. Is it also like night of living dead? If you only watch the film on a superficial level as just another vampire movie you are missing out on all the underlying themes. 

I don‚Äôt feel like getting into all the of themes and how layered the film is because I know you don‚Äôt actually care. But based on overall consensus people do not agree with you. The people who are saying this are either looking for attention or not using their brains. Perhaps both.

replies.author: @russianbot8576
replies.text:
i worry this gets a little conspiratorial, but i totally get this and find myself feeling this at times. i want to offer, however, that when we do this, we conflate 'resulted outcome' with 'intended result'. let me explain, for anyone who doesn't already know:

it isn't any wonder that same mentality that adds diversity to a film for no reason than to try to up profits by demographic-targeting also doesn't see movie production for the sake of artistic creation but as a form of profit machinery. their intent is to squeeze extra money from people who diversity appeals to, or specific demographics, or both. they're not trying to make good or bad movies, but some number of ticket sales.

the _result_ is that a diversity effort is chained to a shitty movie, that was always going to be garbage because it was made to print money. and this compounds in diverse casts being a potential flag for 'mediocre film' along with others (live-action adaptations of animated movie is the twin flag that begins to signal this). we see these patterns whether or not they're intended.

the end result is the same problem. there is no disagreement that throwing marginalised groups under the bus for profits still is only being done because of the underlying white supremacy and/or heteronormativity or so on of the culture allows marginalised groups to take the fall and be blamed for soulless corporate snoozefests, as well.

I've seen a couple comments confused about this, so I'm just putting here that SEAsian means Southeast Asian, a region that includes Myanmar, Vietnam, Laos, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, Indonesia, Cambodia, East Timor, Singapore, and Brunei (Probably missed one). 
Filipinos (not philipinos) aren't considered Pacific Islanders, but they are ethnically Austronesian, like Pacific Islanders.

replies.author: @NurseKayP
replies.text:
@LisaBrown-s8cdegeneracy? I believe that was one of the underlying themes. We are all sinners. Duality. 

I thought the movie was great. It was complex and layered. Thought provoking and many aspects that could be discussed.

I will say I had to look up if Mary had any black ancestry because if she did not I could see how it could be offensive. 

The actress is 1/8th black and played a 1/8th black character. So they weren‚Äôt putting a white woman in our faces trying to convince us she was a black woman. She was obviously white passing based on the one drop rule she would be considered black during that time. Any whites who were aware of her have the slightest bit of black ancestry would treat her just like they did other black women. It seems the actress was meant to have grown up in the black community and that‚Äôs where she feels at home but she doesn‚Äôt fit in there either. So she doesn‚Äôt feel like she belongs in either community and that was part of her struggle with identity and belonging. She seems to feel more at home in the black community but her appearance and presence makes it unsafe for others. She couldn‚Äôt be with the man she loved because it could put them in danger. If she had been caught in the juke it would have endangered everyone. She was a very flawed character. She didn‚Äôt seem to care too much about the safety of the man she ‚Äúloved‚Äù or her friends because she went right to the door of the juke which could endanger everyone. 

She was the ‚Äútragic mulatto‚Äù which is a trope seen in other movies like ‚ÄúImitation of life‚Äù or ‚ÄúPinky‚Äù but I believe both those actresses had zero black ancestry. Her current lived experience wouldn‚Äôt be that of a black woman because she assimilated ans married a white man. But if she grew up in the black community then she would share some of the experiences of other black girls she grew up with but probably be somewhat protected by her proximity to whiteness. 

Some people try to deny mixed race people as black like Tracee Ellis Ross, Zendaya, Thandie Newton, etc. because they aren‚Äôt black enough. Colorism obviously exists as well which adds another layer to the conversation. But it doesn‚Äôt seem fair to mixed race women to be erased because their lived experience is that of a black woman. Similar to any other lighter skinned black woman. Erasing them doesn‚Äôt allow them to have a place in either community. Hailee is white passing so she can assimilate into the white community like she did in reali life and the movie but the same can‚Äôt be said for the women I mentioned above. Same goes for men but I was specifically speaking about women. Barack Obama was the first black president because that‚Äôs how the U.S. views mixed race people. No one was running around saying he was the first mixed race president because his lived experience is that of a black man.

author: @jdeljones
text: I am old enough to remember when a music critic accidentally published their review of Rihanna's ANTI before the album came out with the song titles missing that they were just going to insert into the review once those were revealed. The higher ups had already decided what narrative they wanted to spin with Sinners. The actual box office numbers didn't mean anything. It could have made $100m in the opening weekend and there would have still been a caveat. For the record -- it was projected to open with $30m. So the debut was literally double what the movie execs thought it would be. But instead of focusing on that success and how off their projections were, they want to turn it into some profitability equation that is never done for any non-superhero movie. No one cares about marketing budgets, or the cost to breakeven outside of superhero blockbusters bc those movies are so expensive. At the Academy Awards its a bunch of films that would kill for a $60m opening weekend.

replies.author: @steampunker7
replies.text:
White Irish lad here. I'm a horror hound and always love when the genre is filtered through different cultures, backgrounds, and experiences.  Seeing what particular spin or unique facet is explored in a work from a source you might not immediately expect.  And like Tales from the Hood, Bad Hair, Werewolf Within, and even the Blackening, Sinners delivered with a great hook, solid casting across the board, some gnarly gore, and backdrop that touched on a lot of (for lack of a better term) purely "American" historical experiences, for good and for ill.  

Sure beats another Scream sequel or Saw retread.

replies.author: @NurseKayP
replies.text:
@ruthlesslistener Remmick being an Irish man added a layer of complexity to the film that was really interesting. Ireland has a complex history with colonization and Irish immigrants have a history of being treated poorly in the U.S and not being considered white. 

He was technically the villain but I could understand his motivations. I obviously didn‚Äôt want him to succeed in turning all the characters I really liked but I could sympathize with where he was coming from and his experiences. 

He had to hide his accent and relate to the bigotry of the white couples house he showed up at in order to be let in. He had been in the country 20 years and lived a long time prior to that so who knows what he experienced. He was drawn to Sammie because of the music but was he drawn to the black community for other reasons as well. 

Him showing up was a different feeling than when the klan showed up at the end. They seemed like the real monsters and they were only human beings.

replies.text: ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã@taegotkashhi. Sorry. Didnt see the comments until now. I think i would love it any way but a valid question none the less. My main love for the film was the link between cultures and the use of music and community to over come racism and repression. The irish have a very messed up history in america. Being that they were driven there to escape the horrors inflicted by the brits at home. However, the shit they did to be accepted as white there...... Remmick represents this well. What should have been kin was fed upon to rise. When our cultures were of course, far more linked to the african american experience or the natives than it was any of the other white people there. The complexity of Remmicks inclusion opened up so many conversations on this. That was an aspect i loved and wasnt expecting. I didnt know much about the film when i went. Im not irish american. I fully irish. Born in ireland and have not forgotten our history nor the on going trauma's felt because of it. So i agree with this link between cultures and lived experience. Not to in any way lessen what is still on going in very real terms to this day for black americans. But due to those views. Im always drawn more towards offerings from african americans, native americans, mexican cinema etc and will always rave about and promote movies like sinners. As usual, truly innovative and unique and way more worth spending your money on seeing than yhe usual hollywood shite. Anyway. Im not always the best at articulating myself and thats the best i can do to answer that question. But its a fair question ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è i cant deny i did love the inclusion but in such a fresh way that encourages a bit more of a look at why Ryan chose this direction. It was cool. Loved all the characters though. Not one badly thought out half baked one üëå quick edit. I know the irish are white. I say to be seen as white because at the time when the irish were being forced to leave their homes. They werent seen as white in europe. Often depicted as monkeys etc. To lessen what the british were doing in ireland to the irish at the time. Thats where Remmicks ache when he found Sammie comes in. He saw the similarities in culture. The use of music to process the pain and loss of identity and culture. The similiarities in treatment. I understood it but i also saw the level of pain he caused with his insistance he be included, pandered to and ultimately took over the space. It was fucking brilliant!

text: as a black film student who's worked in the industry, i have a note: most big studio movies have to actually earn 2.5x their budget to be considered profitable because of insane marketing costs, meaning sinners would have to make $225 million to reach that. all major studio movies were held to this standard until the late 2010s + the rise of streaming. because of things like declining theatrical attendance, declining ancillary markets (i.e., DVD sales/rentals), and increased movie budgets across the board, an original R-rated blockbuster that's "profitable" in the traditional sense of the word almost never happens nowadays. all that said, no matter how sinners performs at the box office, it's already a hit. as of writing this, it's crossed $175 million globally, meaning traditional profitability--against a standard almost NO ONE lives up to now--is probably just around the corner barring an unexpected blowout from thunderbolts or mission impossible, neither of which have the buzz that sinners has right now. since WB, the distributor, is under a parent company that also owns a streaming service (max), sinners' streaming debut will also drive profit/subscriptions, and WB could probably even create a bidding war to license it to netflix or another streamer if they wanted to. i say all this to say that not only is sinners an incredible success by today's standards, it would've still been a massive success in the industry heyday of 10+ years ago. the trades and NYT's initial reporting on the film has been so disrespectful, and it's hilarious watching variety try to backtrack now. great video!

@vikkidonn
replies.text:
@ not sure where you get ‚Äúhour long‚Äù from. Nor do I really know what you mean by ‚Äúsurface level‚Äù‚Ä¶.
       There are different genres of film for a reason. There are various techniques in film making as well as writing that come with technical and objective standards. So there are simple preferences in entertainment and then there are those technical critiques that would be based in the technical and objective standards. Such that are taught in say film school? 

          The issue with the two examples you‚Äôve given is that the FILM doesn‚Äôt present its story the way YOU are choosing to perceive it. Just because someone can look at and perceive a message doesn‚Äôt mean that message was intentional or present at all whatsoever. 
         When you claim the vampire to be ‚Äúculture vultures‚Äù you didn‚Äôt explain HOW the FILM actually gives this message at all‚Ä¶. In fact you simply stated it and then moved to your next point. They are vampires yes. However they aren‚Äôt after ‚Äúculture‚Äù . Remmic is LITERALLY after Sammie because of his spiritual gift that would allow remmic to see his people who were killed by the Christian invaders. About 1,000 years before. 
        You‚Äôre proving a point I‚Äôve made several times, which is that this film is being propped up by audience perception and not the actual Merit of the script itself. 
             Also your second ‚Äúexample‚Äù isn‚Äôt an example as it blatantly disregards the film and what was shown to you. The father and daughter worked the store in the ‚Äúblack side‚Äù of town, while the wife and mother worked in a shop on the ‚Äúwhite side‚Äù‚Ä¶.. you and everyone else that paid attention saw this. The Asian couples loyalties or otherwise were never even brought up in film either. Realistically they could have easily been cut and nothing would have changed at all whatsoever. Their being Asian played absolutely zero role in the story outside of historical accuracy. They could have been black and their stories would have still played out the same. Their cultural heritage didn‚Äôt even play a single role except the few seconds their own ancestors were present during the ‚Äúsummoning. 

              The issue is people adding their own narratives and feelings to films. Filling in plot holes in a manner that suits their own preconceived notions instead of being honest and saying what it is. This film had everything going for it except for the script which was a mixed up mess of a story.

replies.text: @vikkidonn I didn‚Äôt listen to any interviews or see trailers before watching the movie so perhaps that plays a role into why I don‚Äôt see a messed up script (there are some things that I think could have been done better like show more people in the juke joint before the battle scene when it appears there are extra people). But then again many others did see both and it seems that it didn‚Äôt ruin the film for most people unlike your point for fantastic beasts. I didn‚Äôt see it as mostly being about white people stealing the blues but about how narratives are used regarding unity and inviting others in but unfortunately often the other people (often White) have ulterior motives that ultimately lead to the usurping of Black people‚Äôs resources, energy, & even life and about the importance of black autonomy. In terms of music, the vampires and the church both tried to take Sammie‚Äôs music/soul away but despite everything he went through, it was worth holding onto & he was able to hold on to it and prosper (don‚Äôt give up bc of enemies or respectability but hold onto authenticity). Just like Slim, he was able to use that pain to inform his music. It‚Äôs ok if it‚Äôs not convincing to you. I think I appreciate more as a movie with fantastical elements than if it were a historical piece- it distinguishes it from previous films that have dealt with White people destroying what Black people built (e.g., Rosewood). I can understand though if someone came mostly for a vampire film why they would be disappointed. Every movie isn‚Äôt for everyone.

replies.author: @vikkidonn
replies.text:
@ I agree that not every film is for everyone. However I look at it from two different angles. As a piece of entertainment I liked it. I really did like it save a few spots here and there that just didn‚Äôt need to be there‚Ä¶.. 
      But from a technical standpoint and what Coogler claimed the film was about this is where I say it‚Äôs messed up. 
         I genuinely believe you can pull truth or perceive lessons from literally anything. The problem I‚Äôve seen happen with this film however isn‚Äôt that. People who didn‚Äôt like that it ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt‚Äù a black vampire movie (like blade is considered) have been shamed by other black people. People who disagree with many of the perceived messages, for example that Mary ‚Äústole‚Äù stacks freedom because he didn‚Äôt love her‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. Like I said some things just aren‚Äôt in the film at all or people are ignoring the film itself. Stack says he loves her multiple times, and Mary changes him after forcibly being changed herself and believing it to be the thing that will free them from the broader racist America. She genuinely felt it was best. And he agreed at the end. But those who disagree with this take away have had their private lives ridiculed. One black creator who has a white Italian wife was slandered so bad he genuinely didn‚Äôt know how to respond. He‚Äôs never done movie reviews and just tried it and was slammed by long time fans and lost subscribers‚Ä¶..

author: @BlackAutMedia
text:
If people are interested in reading more about this topic, "The Hollywood Jim Crow" is basically entirely about this video. This whole attitude toward not funding films primarily by Black creatives while also using the circular reasoning of profitability (even when the evidence directly contradicts it) has decades of historical precedent.

This also should be thought about in reviewing and discussing any Black media because who has access to the space and what kind of commentary the work makes will always be shaped by YT supremacy.

Also good to look into not only does the media manufacture consent around different political issues, but many films, TV series, and video games are influenced and receive consultation and input from government institutions. National Security Cinema details a lot of this in the context of the US government and propaganda quite extensively.

author: @JoeSchmo-oj9px
text:
Hollywood works something like this:

Up and coming young director makes a solid debut. 
Gets more chances and delivers more solid box office success.
Gets a reputation as a dependable force and talent.
Moves up, delivers huge box office successes.
Gets older, starts to dabble in finance and patronage of new talent.
Starts solid production companies that deliver.
More talent attracted, more finance coming in, more success.
Different kind of stories are now possible to be told.
Starts to become a rival and a threat to existing big players.

At which stage do you think Coogler is at and what is it they say about nipping it in the bud?

"Yeah, go ahead and make more movies and money for the financiers but don‚Äôt start getting ideas into your head, young man". That sort of thing.

author: @pinballwitch5256
text:
Well said, like always. The thing you said about Ariel being such a sacred role really struck me. I was an 8 year old sitting literally in the front row opening weekend in 89, and Ariel was the first crack in my trans egg. Seeing this character wanting to be different than how her whole world saw her? It was the start of my journey of understanding myself. No one reveres Ariel more than I do, and when I first heard the casting, my reaction was simply "If even just one 8 year old Black Trans Girl has her own journey start from the remake, then that's worth more to me than any profit the movie could generate. The Little Mermaid changed my life for the better, and I hope the new version helped more kids like me see they weren't wrong for wanting to be themselves.

sorry for the long comment, love ya, Olay!

author: @TheCoolestPetinTown
text: It's Hollywood's worst nightmare because it threatens Hollywood's tendency to sell slop and mediocracy. Think about it, every reboot, remake, and sequel to get that dough. Original ideas have an opportunity cost to studios for every remake, reboot, and sequel they could make and this threatens that. Hollywood only wants to feed us what we're familiar with and Sinners threatens that hegemony. For example, Forrest Gump was held in development hell for so long and other original films get held in development hell because Hollywood doesn't want the big, grand, original ideas that encourage real thinking or entertainment. They want to feed us more of what we're familiar with, so we don't think differently. When people think the same in an industry, it just keeps the feeding the beast. All it takes is a film like this to threaten and that and honestly, it's necessary. We need it. Film is art. Or it should be art, it's been monotonized, chewed up, spit out, taken advantage and people's focus are the most famous stars, most successful stars, profitable franchises, and the latest Marvel film or sports or music celebrity endorsed in film like Space Jam 1 and 2 because music isn't as profitable. You can call me a conspiracy theorist, but there's enough reliable evidence out there to show this is the truth. Just like at how often sequels were made in the Golden Age, 70s, 80s, some of the 90s, vs. the number of sequels now. I can't cross a theatre anymore without seeing a remake, sequel, or continuation on some previous work. It's impossible.

author: @steampunker7
text: It's funny you mention Tarantino because, being fair, Sinners does seem to take more than couple cues from From Dusk Till Dawn.  Same basic premise (crime drama character study takes a hard turn into a "base under siege" story with bloodsuckers.) It just moves the setting from contemporary South West to Jim Crow Deep South.  That's not a criticism, btw.  As Sinners distinguishes itself by digging into the cultural roots of the setting and its characters.  Both narratively and with the visual language of its cinematography.  But it is noteworthy that while From Dusk Till Dawn is lauded, Sinners gets eyed with suspicion.

author: @thedreammweaver6274
text:
A lot of criticism about this movie I‚Äôve seen can be boiled down to ‚ÄúWhy can‚Äôt black people shut up and stop talking about things that are important to them.‚Äù Also just this general attitude I hate where people think that because they don‚Äôt like something the director made the movie as a personal insult to them, I need people to learn how to be normal about disliking things. 

I‚Äôm Black from Mississippi, I‚Äôve lived just outside the delta my whole life and this movie affected me so deeply. Especially the music. Especially the scene with the I Lied To You song which some people are calling unnecessary. Complaining about an extended music scene in a movie about black music makes you sound plain stupid. I also see people saying the movie shouldn‚Äôt expect you to know black history to understand it (nevermind that the plot of Sinners is layered but the sequence of events is pretty easy to understand without having deep prior historical knowledge). I‚Äôve never heard this about other period films. I‚Äôve never heard anyone slam Oppenheimer for expecting you to know bomb history to understand it.

author: @TsubataLately
text:
Wonderful video, Olay! There currently isn't a release date for Sinners where I live, so I've been careful about which videos I've watched about on the topic, but I'm glad I chose yours.

Your analysis is so spot on. Black people are only allowed success when we humble ourselves. And even then only a few chosen voices. And even then only so long as they're useful. And even then only as long as it doesn't cause too much of a stir in the broader community. Pushback will always be punished and no loyalty will ever be given. 

As someone who loves having serious discussions about film and television, I just keep my opinions to myself if the topic even remotely concerns Black people. There's no such thing as good faith discourse. There are always voices only looking for ways to tear Black people down.
